title: Day 7 - Become a Detective
mainPromise: You will collect market clues about pricing, buyers, and competing offers, then convert them into practical decisions for your offer.

teachings.title: Evidence beats opinions
teachings.content:
You do not need a perfect market study. You need enough clues to avoid obvious mistakes: pricing far below value, selling to the wrong people, or offering something no one buys.

Market clues are everywhere: listings, landing pages, reviews, forums, and job posts. You are not copying anyone. You are learning what customers already pay for and how they describe the problem.

Your job today is to collect evidence in a consistent way so you can compare offers and extract patterns.
teachings.soWhat: If you do not collect evidence, your offer will be built on guesses and you will waste time rewriting later.

teachings.title: Patterns reveal what to offer
teachings.content:
A single example can mislead you. Patterns protect you. Look for repeated elements: common deliverables, common timelines, common pricing bands, and common pain language.

Also note gaps. A gap is not no competitors. A gap is a mismatch, like offers that are expensive and slow, or offers that are broad and unclear. Your advantage can be clarity, speed, focus, or a better-defined outcome.

You will convert patterns into decisions: what you include, what you exclude, and where you can price without feeling dishonest.
teachings.soWhat: If you do not extract patterns, your evidence stays as noise instead of guiding choices.

teachings.title: Turn clues into next steps
teachings.content:
Detective work should end in action. Today you will produce three outputs that directly shape your offer: a target price range, a scope boundary, and a channel hypothesis.

A channel hypothesis is your best guess about where the first customers will come from, based on what you observed. If discussions happen on a forum, that may be your first outreach. If offers sell on marketplaces, that may be your first listing.

Keep it simple. Your first customers often come from direct outreach and small communities, not from elaborate marketing.
teachings.soWhat: If you do not convert clues into decisions, research becomes a hiding place.

doBlocks.title: Collect 10 market clues
steps: Find 10 examples related to your primary idea (offers, listings, or discussions).
For each, capture price, scope, and who it is for.
Save links and a one-line note.

items.label: Saved 10 links related to your primary idea
items.evidencePrompt: List 10 URLs or reference links you collected.

items.label: Recorded price points for at least 6 of them
items.evidencePrompt: List at least 6 prices with currency and the matching link label.

items.label: Recorded scope notes for all 10
items.evidencePrompt: Provide 10 one-line scope notes, one per link.

items.label: Recorded target customer signals for all 10
items.evidencePrompt: Provide 10 one-line who it is for notes, one per link.

doBlocks.example: Link: Example offer page. Price: $99. Scope: One setup, one revision, delivered in 72 hours. Customer signal: Freelancers, solo founders.

doBlocks.title: Extract pricing and scope patterns
steps: Group your evidence into 2 to 3 price bands.
List the most common deliverables and promises you saw.
Identify one gap you can target and one thing you will not compete on.

items.label: Created 2 to 3 price bands with examples in each
items.evidencePrompt: Write 2 to 3 price bands and list examples under each band.

items.label: Listed the top 5 common deliverables or scope elements
items.evidencePrompt: List 5 deliverables/scope elements that appeared repeatedly.

items.label: Listed the top 5 common customer pain phrases or triggers
items.evidencePrompt: List 5 phrases or triggers customers use to describe the problem.

items.label: Identified one gap and one not-competing-on decision
items.evidencePrompt: Write two lines: one gap you will target and one area you will not compete on.

doBlocks.example: Bands: $25 to $50 quick templates, $75 to $150 done-for-you setup. Gap: Fast done-for-you with fixed scope and clear handoff. Not competing on: Unlimited revisions.

doBlocks.title: Make evidence-based decisions
steps: Choose your target price and one backup price.
Define your offer boundaries in 5 bullets.
Choose one primary channel to test first and one secondary.

items.label: Selected a target price and a backup price using your bands
items.evidencePrompt: Write your target price and backup price with a one-line justification for each.

items.label: Wrote 5 scope boundaries for your service
items.evidencePrompt: List 5 boundaries that define what is included and excluded.

items.label: Chose a primary and secondary acquisition channel
items.evidencePrompt: Name two channels and write one line on why each fits.

items.label: Wrote one test plan for tomorrow's customer coffee exercise
items.evidencePrompt: Write 3 lines describing what you will test about the customer tomorrow.

doBlocks.example: Target price: $89 because it sits in the done-for-you band and supports a 48-hour promise. Boundaries: One workspace, one workflow, one revision, no ongoing support, delivered digitally.

outputs: Evidence list of 10 links with prices, scope, and customer signals
Extracted patterns: price bands, common deliverables, common pain language
Decisions: target price, scope boundaries, and channels to test
A short test plan for tomorrow
wrap.tomorrowPreview: Tomorrow you will simulate a realistic customer conversation to clarify what they care about, what they fear, and what would make them buy.
